Fields.DialogueText: Emden, are we ready to...
Helloooo, Captain!
Guten Tag, mein Kapitän! The Schüler are pleased to see you!

Fields.MenuText: What sort of class is this?
Students? These are members of the crew.
Well, this is a first.

Fields.DialogueText: A Geschichtsstunde, one open for any of the Matrosen who wish to participate.
Hello, class.
I want my Schüler to learn what the Welt has to offer so that they may be well prepared in Leben.
As long as these classes don't get in the way of the crew's duties, you're welcome to continue as long as you like.
At the Schleifsteinklasse, we help our Schüler to excel both in and out of the Klassenraum. And the Lehrerbund is very interested indeed in my Resultaten!
*ALARM*
Also gut Klasse, this is what we practiced for! Everyone auf Station in an orderly fashion!
This ought to be interesting...
@BATTLE
Selbstverständlich! Who else would I be teaching aboard this Schiff?
There's a first Mal for everything, Kapitän.
Huh. Can't go wrong with teaching history.
Good to see you, Kapitän!
You too, Emden.
I am glücklich to report that all of my Schüler are safe and vollzählig.
What is the Status of the Rest of the Mannschaft?

Fields.MenuText: That's a good question...
Everyone is accounted for.
All the survivors are accounted for.

Fields.DialogueText: A Kapitän always needs to be aware of the Status of the Mannschaft. Perhaps a Lektion on the matter is angebracht.
Hurra!
Such Tragödie, even in Triumph.
What are your students doing now?
*gestures at paints and easels* We can hang the Bilder in the halls of the Schiff. Everyone needs a kreativen offset. It is rejuvenating for the Seele.
You have a creative outlet of your own, don't you? Based on what I've glimpsed in your quarters...
How frivol of you, Kapitän. In my Freizeit-
It would be interesting to see how it's done.
What do you do in your Freizeit, Kapitän?
*ALARM*
Does battling Morganas count?
Leider nein. Perhaps you should participate in my Unterricht sometime and discover a Leidenschaft.
@BATTLE
We won't forget the people we've lost.
So...
That's "Fräulein Emden," Kapitän. At least when we're on duty. I'm a teacher after all.
And you have a reputation to maintain. Got it. And your class?
I suspect that "free time" can be measured in seconds...
-  I create Buddelschiffe.
Ships in bottles? I hope that's not a symbolic cry for help.
Natürlich nicht! Maybe you can see for yourself sometime soon.
What are you reading, Emden? New lesson plan?
I've finished my Pläne for today. Kapitän, look at this Vehikel!
Well, that's...
It's the Volkswagen! The people's car, capable of reaching a Tempo of one hundred Kilometer pro hour! 100 km/h! It's my Ziel to obtain one of my own.
Why don't you save up and buy one?
However, the Volkswagenwerke have completely halted the Produktion - and they had only barely started. So this verkompliziert the matter quite a bit.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure you'll be able to get one eventually.
What do you do now?
Maybe it's time for a new goal?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm hopeful that will be the Fall.
I need to think of a Plan to acquire one.
I like the Ziel I have. Automobile offer a sense of individueller freedom that trains and Busse do not.
Why don't you get another car? There are plenty of others out there.
But it's cute! Perfekt for me. Keine Sorge, I'll figure out some way of getting my hands on one.
*ALARM*
Een Stapp na d' anner. A Walküre must live like the Leute she defends! Now, let us defend them.
@BATTLE
"Fünf Mark die Woche musste du sparen, willst du im eigenen Wagen fahren." That's the Idee.
What about driving it?
Willkommen in meiner Werkstatt, Kapitän. This is where I like to spend my Freizeit.
I need to ask, how do you construct a ship in a bottle?
I am glad you asked, Kapitän! It's a simpler Prozess. Essentially, the Schiff is largely constructed outside the Buddel.
Once completed, the whole Schiff goes into the Buddel, but flat. The mouth of the Buddel determines the width of the Rumpf.
Erecting the flat Aufbauten is the trickiest part.
But these are modern battleships with minimal rigging and large guns. How do you get those on the ship that's already in the bottle?
I work from the back of the Buddel to the mouth and apply each Aufbaute individually, where needed.
Are all these ships yours?
Some are for other Walküren. This one on the Werkbank is the HMS Hood - at Lady Hood's own request. It's such a beautiful Schiff, isn't it?

Fields.MenuText: That seems like a lot of work for a simple hobby.
This is very impressive!
How much would you charge for something like this?

Fields.DialogueText: It requires Konzentration and keeps the mind sharp. And seeing the Ergebnisse is satifying.
Danke, Kapitän. I practiced a lot for this.
Why? Do Kapitäne get a cut from the work of a Walküre?
Hm. So you could say that all of these ships are portraits.
In a way, ja.
*ALARM*
I hope you have enjoyed yourself seeing my Werkstatt. Let's hope it isn't destroyed im Kampf.
@BATTLE
That's what the yarn is for? Pulling up the masts and whatnot?
Ja! Sehr gut!
What? No. I just want to know how much one would cost.
Ah! Preise vary based on what you want and how detailed you want it to be.
*ALARM*
I'm sorry you had to sacrifice valuable workshop time for this.
Sarcasm, Kapitän?
Not at all. You just pulled... what, an eighteen-hour shift?
Merely a small Investition in the future of my Schüler and my Volk!
@BATTLE
Terrific battle, Emden.
I'm in the midst of thinking and praying on my Plan. All Optionen must be weighed before I can come to a decision.
Praying? Yes, you are a devout...
Evangelisch. I am a devout Evangelisch. I need to decide whether spending Geld on a decidedly selfish purpose is wise at this point in time.
You don't want to set a bad example for your students?
Exakt. I am an Autoritätsperson, and it's vital that I take that Position seriously.

Fields.MenuText: So bribing an official for one probably isn't an option.
If you have the money, you might as well use it. It's yours to do with as you choose.
Are you sure you honestly want a Volkswagen?

Fields.DialogueText: I would say so, Kapitän. As well as leveraging my unique Status as a Walküre. If I am an Avatar des Volkes, I must labor as they do.
The Kauf is not my sole concern. What impact me having an Auto will have on others, how the Geld I spend might be used... There are many issues.
Of that I am certain. I am no less one of the Volk than those who serve aboard me.
Well, I'm sure you'll figure it out. You're as level-headed as they come, Emden.
I try my Bestes. Danke.
Danke. And you also.
So. While we're waiting on reports - any forward progress on your plans to acquire a car?
Kapitän! I have made an Entscheidung.
Sounds... momentous. I'd like to hear it.
I am going to hold off on the Volkswagen until the Krieg is over.

Fields.MenuText: Sounds like a plan.
What are you going to do now?
What made you come to this conclusion?

Fields.DialogueText: As they say, gau un good is nich alltied binanner.
I will continue teaching my Schüler and preparing them for life after the Krieg.
Since Sprit and Teile would both be in short supply during the Krieg, it ultimately made more sense to wait.
To serve the Volk is a greater good than driving like it. Someday, in the Zukunft, I'll be able to take to the Autobahn, just like I've always envisioned.
*ALARM*
What a Schande. I was going to go celebrate my Abstinenz with nice, hot Pharisäer...
Perhaps the Morganas need an education on not interrupting?
Taking the Feind by surprise is a good Taktik. I actually admire them for that.
@BATTLE
That's a respectable decision, Emden. I know how much you wanted one.
Well, worth the wait or not, I hope you won't have to wait too long. I know how much you wanted it.
Newspaper call. Newish edition of the Ostfriesische Tageszeitung for you, Emden.
Well... I see the need to harmonize Nachrichten, especially during a Krieg, but I wonder sometimes how much Gleichschaltung is too much.
What do you mean?
The Evangelische faith isn't one faith in Germany, but two. The Calvinistisch-Reformierte and the Lutherische church. In good German Tradition they balance each other out and tolerate each other.
For example... the Emder Konkordate of 1599 regulated how my people could practice Reformed services in the otherwise Lutheran Ostfriesland.
Nowadays there seems to be a new enforced Spaltung instead between the Deutsche Kirche and the Bekennende Kirche.
"Spaltung." So... more hacksaw surgery than reform?
I don't know about your Metapher... but not a Reform in the literal sense, nein.

Fields.MenuText: So the changes you're seeing... You don't think they're good.
I don't know how much I appreciate tradition as a whole.
What about new traditions?

Fields.DialogueText: I think harmonizing Staat and Kirche too much will dampen the faith of many.
Tradition can be comforting! Think of Feier und Festtage - no matter the Kultur, they bring feelings of Nostalgie and Freude.
New Traditionen can be wonderful, Kapitän. But when they come at the cost of old Traditionen, well... I tend to worry, and about some more than others.
Why do you like tradition so much?
Traditionen support Kultur. They give us a sense of Identität and remind us of where we came from.
*ALARM*
Would you consider fighting Morganas a tradition?
That is one Tradition I could certainly do without.
@BATTLE
Vielen Dank, Kapitän. It's no Rhein-Ems-Zeitung, but it gets the job done.
Another newspaper?
The old Emder newspaper. That was before the Reichsleiter Presse shut down the smaller publishers.
Not exactly spoiled for choice when it comes to news, are you?
The Germany that I love seems to be breaking away from that Tradition.
Kapitän! Kapitän! 'T is dröck!
What's all the shouting about?
It's been stohlen!
What has?
A Gutenberg!

Fields.MenuText: A what?
That's another automobile, right? Perhaps a motorcycle?
As in the printer? Publisher?

Fields.DialogueText: A Gutenberg Bibel. Printed in the mid 15th century by Johannes Gutenberg. Originally there were 200 Kopien, but few survive today... maybe one fewer, now!
The Gutenberg Bibel is a rare and very famous book. There are only a few dozen copies in existence.
I'm glad to hear you know of him, Kapitän. He only revolutionierte the history of the World!
And one of the Gutenberg Bibles was stolen?
The Kopie from Göttingen. It's a complete, two-volume copy printed on Pergament.
The Gutenberg Bibel needs to be found. Casting aside religiöse connotations, it is an Artifakt of German Geschichte that must be saved.
I wonder if these Morganas took it?
Then a dark Storm waits for them on the Horizont.
@BATTLE
Hello, Fräulein Emden. "Students."
Would you care to join my Unterricht today, Kapitän?
We are going over the Bedeutung of the Gutenberg-Presse for the upcoming Mission.

Fields.MenuText: Sure, extra education can't hurt.
Sure, I've been having trouble sleeping. This might help.
Uh... why?

Fields.DialogueText: It's so pleasant to see a positive Einstellung!
Kapitän, you really ought to have a better Einstellung. The Schüler look up to you!
Take Platz, Kapitän! You'll find this useful.
Psst, hey! Yeah, you! Good work with the guns during our last battle.
Oh, thank you, Captain!
Kapitän? Can you tell us the answer to my question?

Fields.MenuText: What was the question again?

Fields.DialogueText: Once again, for those of you whose Aufmerksamkeit was elsewhere, in what Jahr was the Buchdruck invented?
Korrekt, Kapitän! You almost fooled me... I thought you weren't paying attention.
Das ist falsch! Please do not distract the other Schüler, Kapitän.
In this Klasse, Kapitän, you are held to the same Standards as my Schüler. As Kapitän you should even be a Vorbild for the others.
Now, even though Holzformschneider existed before this time, it took a very long time to create a Seite. Each one had to be carved out individuell.
The Typendruckpresse could have Buchstaben rearranged, taking much less time to create each Seite.
*ALARM*
That's all for now. Kapitän, please try not to talk in your Schlaf.
What? No! I w-wasn't...
Or at least stay on Thema.
@BATTLE
How did your meeting with government officials go, Fräulein Emden?
The Regierung suspects that the Sowjets might have taken the Bibel. But I'm skeptisch.
Likewise. I just don't see how Moscow would gain from it.

Fields.MenuText: Where else do you think the book could be?
How are you going to find the book's whereabouts?
How much do you think that book is worth?

Fields.DialogueText: Given the Wert and Seltenheit of the Buch, I'm certain it was an Auftragstat.
Checking the Schwarzmarkt is good, in the event that the Dieb wanted to make quick Geld.
I would say... about half a million Reichsmark? But culturally speaking, it is unbezahlbar.
We're still short on actual suspects, though.
Man sall nich ehrder danzen, as de Fiedel geiht. It would be best to observe and see what we can find.
*ALARM*
While fighting these Morganas at the same time.
That's how it is.
@BATTLE
So maybe some private individual contracted thieves to retrieve the book? I could see it...
What's the latest on the missing Gutenberg? Any intel?
Not much, Kapitän.
But I have made contacts in the Sowjetunion, many parts of Europa, Großbritannien, and Amerika. We'll hear something soon enough.

Fields.MenuText: That seems a rather broad area to cover.
What if you never find the book?
What if the book is destroyed out of spite?

Fields.DialogueText: It is best to be as thorough as möglich to systematically eliminate the variables.
We can't have such negative thoughts, Kapitän! I need to show my Schüler how due diligence reaps Resultate.
I don't know what would be worse! Missing entirely or maliciously mangled... Just from thinking such thoughts wird mir schlecht.
Where are we headed next?
I don't want to go anywhere in particular until we have found the location of the Buch. Not being fixed to one spot allows us to get to it schneller.
So we stay put, then?
At the very least it allows me more time to work on my Stundenplan.
You'd mentioned that. Any news from the Lecturers Federation?
Intermittierende Korrespondenzen, Kapitän. They're still shaping jurisdiction and authority within the Universitäten... not to mention standardizing the Curriculum.
That's why they've taken an interest in me! What better source for teaching German Geschichte than a literal embodiment of the Nation?
There's quite a few of you Belles, though.
Tatsächlich. But maybe I'm the most suited for such a matter with all my scholatischem Wissen.
*ALARM*
You've got to be alive to teach. Let's move.
A very keen Observation.
@BATTLE
Good news, Kapitän!
Did you find who took the book?
Ja, Kapitän! It was...

Fields.MenuText: Let me guess: it was certainly the Soviets.
It was the Italians.
It was the Japanese.

Fields.DialogueText: It was not the Sowjets. That is, wie schon gesagt, jumping to conclusions.
That is incorrect. The Italiener have their own Kopien at the Vatikan, though imperfect.
An interesting outside bet! Aber falsch.
Well, I'm all ears to hear who took the book and why.
According to my Informationen the Buch was stolen by an independent group of Dieben. Eleven international criminals of Meisterdiebe.
And do you know why?
That's where it gets seltsam. They've made a Spiel of trying to steal priceless items from around the Welt. It's Sport to them.
Do you know where they're keeping the book?
*ALARM*
Dunners! I must leave this open. After the Gefecht, I will tell you where the Buch is... and more.
@BATTLE
... People get strange when they think the world is ending.
There you are, Emden. Finish the story! I can't take the anticipation.
Very well, Kapitän.
The Buch is in the hands of a private collector in Amerika. Somewhere in the Florida Keys...

Fields.MenuText: So some mystery person from Florida contracted this group of thieves to steal the book?
The Florida Keys? That's the last place I would look.
I'm glad I didn't put the blame on the Soviets.

Fields.DialogueText: Das ist korrekt, Kapitän.
Things are usually in the last place we look for them.
It is never a good Idee to judge prematurely and falsely blame others. It is best to gather Fakten before making a decision.
This collector, do they collect books specifically? Is that why they wanted a book as valuable as this one?
Interestingly enough, it appears that they are a Sammler of mystic and supernatural oddities, not of Bücher specifically...
So why one of the rarest bibles?
Remember that I said the Bibel was made with Pergament? The Sammler, apparently, believes that it isn't animal skin, but human. Therefore it holds some sort of mystical powers.
*ALARM*
That's... certainly mystifying.
@BATTLE
Mysterien later, Kapitän. We must stave off the great Mysterium of death.
But... I mean, this is a Gutenberg Bible. Its provenance is going to be immaculate, and it's one of the most thoroughly studied books in the world.
Ja.
And they think it's bound in human skin? Really?
A U-boot friend of mine tells me it's a story that dates back two hundred years. The more it's denied, the more its adherents believe there's a Vertuschung.
Well, I have good news. I successfully pitched Command a rescue mission to the Keys.
Natürlich! The latest intelligence states that the Sammler acquired this Buch as a gift to his Ehefrau.
I think he is waiting to get the Buch authenticated before making any announcements. We can use that to our Vorteil.
How so?
We can use that Zeit to get to the Florida Keys and track down the Bibel.

Fields.MenuText: So to Florida we go?
After we get to Florida, what's your plan to get the book? We can't just charge in.
This person sounds similar to you, biding his time before making a move.

Fields.DialogueText: Korrekt, Kapitän. To Florida we go.
After we get there, I think I will pose as an Gutachter, but I need to work out that plan before committing to it.
There are some similarities there, certainly. But I have more Respekt for the Buch than to treat it as some... gift.
It's such a sensitive Einsatz and we must manage so many Aufgaben at once. I have lessons to plan and lectures to compose for the NSLB...
And Morganas to fight...
Korrekt, Kapitän. Let's be quick about it.
@BATTLE
Ah, wunderbar! My Schüler have learned much from their Exkursion.
You're referring to your spies.
All right, let's go over this plan once more.
To get the Buch, I'm going to pose as a Gutachter of okkulte Artefakte - a false Identiät has already been arranged. Because I'm German, it naturally makes my interest in the Bibel more credible.
You can't go far from the ship, though.
That is fine. We can dock in the Hafen and then they can come to me. We'll need to hide the Flaggen to avoid detection, natürlich, but that should be fine.
I'll alter my Aufmachung, make it look as if I'm simply an academic pressed into service on a Kriegsschiff. In this Krieg, it's not uncommon.

Fields.MenuText: What if the collector doesn't want to give up the books?
What is your contingency if the collector doesn't show?
This sounds good to me!

Fields.DialogueText: If he chooses not to give up the Buch, we can take it back by force. The key to success is to be convincing.
I am certain that he will show, as he wants to get the Buch verified before giving it as a gift. Who better than a German Gutachter?
We will still have to work out the Details, but the crude Gerüst stands.
*ALARM*
Maybe you can take a few outfit pointers from these Morganas. I mean, if macabre is what you're going for...
Not a bad Idee, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
Kapitän! I need your opinion!
I'm all ears.
I need the Mannschaft on Deck to wear nondescript clothing, so as not to draw attention to the Schiff. Should I go with the blue or tan Uniformen?
Tan would be fine, I think. Most of them can stay below, of course.
Perfekt. You heard the Kapitän, Jungs un Wichter! Change into these Uniformen!
Are the flags changed?
Jawohl, Kapitän.
Excellent. We're within sight of the Florida Keys, so you'll be able to put your plan into action before you know it.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think we will be convincing enough?
Why do you have some of your ship bottles?
Where did you get all of those extra uniforms?

Fields.DialogueText: The Schiff will be fine. I just hope I will be convincing enough.
Ah! I thought I might bring them with me - add support to my sachverständigen appearance.
Ah, you know I have many Kontakte, Kapitän. They were of great Hilfe in this matter.
You should add some dust to your clothes. Make it look as if you spend all your time with antiquated, forgotten items.
Clevere Idee, Kapitän! I like the way you think.
*ALARM*
It appears that our lack of Flaggen has little Effekt on whether the Morganas consider us Beute.
@BATTLE
Well, we've arrived in the Keys...
What do you think, Fräulein Emden?
This humidity is getting to me. Perhaps a nice, cool Key Lime Pie would alleviate it...

Fields.MenuText: I should pick one up while we're at port.
I would have agreed with you in the past. Your German desserts have ruined other sweets for me.
I've never had key lime pie before. Maybe I'll try one while we're here.

Fields.DialogueText: Lecker. Though I can't wait to get back to Germany to indulge in a gebackenen Apfelring... or three.
You have very strong views on what is only a Dessert, Kapitän.
That sounds like a wunderbare Idee. Expand your kulinarisches knowledge, Kapitän!
1WO Pitchford!
Yes, Schiffsdame Emden?
Get the Sammler and bring him to meet me at the Pier.
Where do you want me, Fräulein Emden?
You stay with me as a Zeuge. We don't know him or what he is capable of, so it's best to have another Amtsträger.
*ALARM*
We should take care of these Morganas!
Preferably before our Gast arrives. I'm told he prefers to avoid such Aufregung.
@BATTLE
Ma'am, this is Santos, the collector.
It's a pleasure to meet you.
Let's get down to it. I don't have all day to be waiting on introductions to be finished!
Let's get started then, shall we? This does appear to be a complete set. You wish to know if this is an authentic Gutenberg?
I don't doubt the authenticity. I want to know what the pages are made from. What type of vellum is it?
Let's have a look...
Hmmm...
Well, is it what I am looking for or not?

Fields.MenuText: These things take time. You don't want to rush an expert.
Santos is right. Better hurry up!
I think I am going to go get some key lime pie...

Fields.DialogueText: I will come to a conclusion soon enough.
I am going as fast as is required. Such an artifact deserves the utmost care.
That might be a good idea, Kapitän. I have this under control.
Wh... where did this sudden chill come from?
*ALARM*
Better hurry it up.
I must consult my records. Stay with this officer. I will return once the battle is won.
@BATTLE
Thank you for waiting.
I've waited around long enough... What's the answer?
Well, it is a very nice book, but made of authentic calfskin.
That is not what I was wanting to hear.
It's also not a real Gutenberg Bible. See here, this illumination at the top of the page is the wrong color. It is still a very nice book, though.
Who did you get this set from? I'm afraid they pulled one over on you.
Unbelievable. What am I going to do with two fake books?
It is still a nicely bound set. I have a client in Leningrad who has been looking for a nicely bound older book, and I'd be happy to buy these volumes from you.
I've certainly spent enough money on fakes.
So now is a time to recoup some of your losses. I shall give you a moment to deliberate.

Fields.MenuText: I think he's going to go for it.
I don't think he's going to go for it.
You don't want to keep it?

Fields.DialogueText: Schsch.
Not helpful, Kapitän.
My Herz yearns for it, Kapitän. But I know in my Innersten it is not mine to keep.
All right, it's a deal.
Wonderful. Come with me and we'll work out the particulars.
Better hold off for now. We've got some Morganas making a bid of their own.
@BATTLE
I can't believe that worked! Lovt Gott!
Let's get both of these volumes to Germany sooner rather than later.
I'm charting the course now!
I must ask, though. Were the Bibles real?
Of course they are echt.
No, what I mean is... were they made from human skin?
Sorry to disappoint your taste for the Makabre. They were not.
Gutenberg had finanzielle troubles as it was producing these Bücher on Papier and Pergament. In fact, an Investor took over the pressing out of Frustration.

Fields.MenuText: What happened to Gutenberg?
Where on earth did the story come from, then?
What is going to happen to the collector?

Fields.DialogueText: He tried to print other Bücher, yet was unsuccessful. The Bischoff of Mainz gave him zumindest a Pension.
That is a Rätsel. I could ask my U-boot friend, but I'm afraid her answer would be... long. And schlußendlich unhelpful.
My guess is he might have some words with the Diebe who supposedly failed him.
I still can't believe we got Command to fund the purchase.
Then where did we get Gutenberg Bible money?
"Fünf Mark die Woche musste du sparen, willst du im eigenen Wagen fahren," remember?
Emden, you didn't have to do that!
Ah... about that, Kapitän. I personally assured them en route to the Keys that that would not be nötig.
Though in this case I suppose it would be "Frugality over many a day will buy a Bibel on a Walküre's pay."
I suppose I did not. But I have already made sacrifices for the Menschen. This is just one more.
That's admirable, Emden. It'll save Command a lot of money too.
Langfristig, ja. I kratzte zusammen and saved everywhere I could, but I may have asked for a Gehaltsvorschuß of some magnitude.
*ALARM*
Also, dann! Shall we go earn our Lebensunterhalt?
@BATTLE
A salary advance? You're going to be paying this off? No, I'm going to get that-
Is it time to celebrate?
Ja! Let's get to my Globus.
It isn't time for a lesson!
There's a compartment inside the globe where I keep the Rum. But only a small Tropfen of it into the Pharisäer. I live on a tight Budget now.
You have a taste for apples.
I use Äpfel to illustrate to my Schöler the importance of being well-arrondiert.
Finding and getting the books back certainly shows the students what they can accomplish with research and determination.
Was it wrong, though, to lie to the Sammler to retrieve the Bücher? I don't want to give my Schöler the impression that lying is akzeptabel.
He stole the volumes in the first place. He was in the wrong.
But is wrong plus wrong really right?
This was the approach that seemed most likely to succeed without violence. I don't think it's appropriate to say that was wrong.
I just hoffe I can be forgiven for deceiving him.

Fields.MenuText: You did buy the books yourself. That counts for something.
You might get a detention at best.
I forgive you.

Fields.DialogueText: Das stimmt, Kapitän. Maybe I will be forgiven.
How do you speculate Gott will let me nachsitzen? Will he give me Doppelschichten? I'm already on duty 24 hours am Tag.
I appreciate that, Kapitän, but I seek Absolution from a higher Autorität.
Let's not put our spirits down, but celebrate accomplishing the mission.
*ALARM*
The Feier will have to wait for now. Life is full of turns that take Priorität over one another. Bis wir uns wiedersehen, Pharisäer.
@BATTLE
Some slices of Apfel with it?
Back in Bremerhaven! This is as close as we get to Göttingen.
Are the officials coming here?
That's korrekt, Kapitän. The proper authorities are coming here to take back the Buch. They will be in the Hafen soon.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think they'll give you a reward?
Do you think Santos will come after you, should he realize what you did?
I'm glad it's safe now.

Fields.DialogueText: Knowing the Bücher are being returned to their rightful Besitzer is all the reward I seek... Apfelringe would be nice, however.
I don't suspect he will. The Buch was not made from the Materialien he was seeking, after all.
As safe as it can be. It will be in the hands of Lehrern and not... Apparatschiks, to borrow a Sowjetwort.
Now, I am off to hold a Vorlesung at the local Universität. You're welcome to join! It's one of mine that I plan on presenting to the NSLB.

Fields.MenuText: I have strategies to plot against the Morganas.
Okay, I have nothing else to do right now...
Oh, uh... Look at the time! I need to be... somewhere!

Fields.DialogueText: A wise decision, Kapitän.
Make sure you pay attention. You have Studenten looking up to you.
I'll take that as a nein...
*ALARM*
It looks like my Vorlesung will have to be postponed. I'd had a Test planned and everything... Well, the NSLB will just have its results another day.
@BATTLE
Fräulein Emden? Is everything all right?
You look... strange.
Ik glöv't neet, Kaptain!

Fields.MenuText: What happened? Did the German officials not want the volumes after all?
Did your students stage a coup?
You've determined that I should take up baking.

Fields.DialogueText: Watt? After all this effort and Geld spent, why wouldn't they want the Bannen back?
I wish them Glück if they ever try.
Watt? Why not? You could supply me with gebackenen Apfelringen.
What happened with the government officials?
They took back the Bücher. However, as a reward... they gave me a Volkswagen! Daar doo ik nix up ut!
You're kidding.
I'm not!
Well, I guess it's good you didn't buy one earlier.
That is the benefit of weighing all Optionen before making a decision.
Spoken like a true bottleship builder.
I'll have to find a Garage to store it in für's Erste, until I will be able to use it.
Speaking of space...
Kapitän?
Fräulein Emden, why is there a horde of university students aboard this ship?
Ah, that's the other thing I wanted to tell you. These are the Studenten I guest lectured for. They're on a Forschungsreise from the Universität at Göttingen.
*ALARM*
Make sure they disembark before we go after this Morgana group.
Natürlich, Kapitän. This was never part of their Curriculum.
@BATTLE
So what happens to the car now?
Fräulein Emden, there you are. I've been looking all over the ship for you.
Sie sind weg, Kapitän! I don't know what's happened!
Slow down, what's going on?
Meine Studenten! They're missing!
Where was the last place they were seen?
They had left the Schiff only an hour earlier, after one of my Vorlesungen on the Reformation. An Offizier was accompanying them back to their homes. Every one of them has disappeared.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think they were kidnapped?
Is the officer also missing?
How long have they been gone?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know, Kapitän. But it's unlikely they all just wandered off.
The Offizier they were with is also missing.
Not long, Kapitän.
Do you think those eleven thieves are behind this?
Why would they do that?
If Santos is spreading the word that they gave him the wrong volumes, they might be out for revenge.
It might have been them, but it might have been...
*ALARM*
... die Nixen!
Let's keep cool and not jump to any conclusions, remember? After we defeat the Morganas here, we will see if they have your students.
@BATTLE
Still no leads on the location of your students...
We will systematisch search. We will use my Kontakte to relay back Erkenntnisse.
Oh, I hope they are safe!

Fields.MenuText: There's no news yet on them - let's be optimistic.
I hope they're safe too.
Maybe put notices in the paper from the last port town we were in?

Fields.DialogueText: We don't have time to be optimistisch!
If anything happens to them, I'd never be able to forgive myself.
That is a gute Idee. I have already dispatched Spione to that Hafen to gather any leads.
We can't forget the missing officer.
Ja, if that Offizier contacts the ship, I also want to know when the Nachricht was sent and its origin. We can't leave any stone on the other.
Whoever took my Studenten will regret even thinking of such an Idee.

Fields.MenuText: We'll find your kids, Emden.
We've got to track them down and make the kidnappers pay.

Fields.DialogueText: Danke sehr, Kapitän. I'd never forgive myself if they were lost...
Danke sehr, Kapitän. I wouldn't trust anyone else with this Suche.
I'm sure the League will be watching.
Oh, hang the Lehrerbund! Bürokraten und Parteigänger allesamt. My Studenten are in Gefahr!
Letting our nerves run away with us won't help. Listen...
